attributes.description: The son of King Daśaratha and Kaikeyí who refuses the throne of Ayodhyá out of devotion to his brother Ráma.
The eldest son of Daśaratha, currently in exile in the forest, whom Bharat seeks to bring back to the throne.
The deceased King of Ayodhyá whose death followed the banishment of his son Ráma.
The chief household priest and sage skilled in the lore of royal duty, who counsels Bharat.
The wife of Ráma, who accompanies him in his forest exile.
The loyal brother of Ráma who serves him in the forest and kept watch while he slept.
The King of the Nishádas and a loyal ally of Ráma who guards the crossing of the Gangá.
The younger brother of Ráma and Bharat, who accompanies Bharat on the journey to the forest.
The royal charioteer and counselor who manages the logistics of the march.
The mother of Bharat whose actions led to Ráma's exile and Daśaratha's death.
The mother of Ráma and chief queen, grieving for her son and late husband.
The holy river where the army halts and where Ráma crossed into the deeper wilderness.
The town on the banks of the Gangá ruled by King Guha.
The ancient sacred scriptures in which the priest Vaśishmha and others are deeply read.

attributes.context: Brothers; Bharat considers Ráma the rightful king and his father-figure.
Spiritual advisor who urges Bharat to take the throne.
Loyal allies; Guha refers to himself as Ráma's slave and friend.
Mother and son; Bharat blames her for the tragedy of the royal family.
Brother and devoted protector during exile.
Charioteer and counselor following the prince's orders for the march.
Brothers who share their grief and purpose in finding Ráma.
Bharat halts his massive army at this location on the banks of the Gangá.
